results.headline: Stumbling Into Divorce
results.summary_short: “Goodbye to All That” tracks an amiably self-centered guy (Paul Schneider) through a divorce and the perils of Internet dating.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye to All That

results.headline: The Bloom Is Off the Rose, the Cap Off the Toothpaste
results.summary_short: Sophie Fillières’s “If You Don’t, I Will” looks at an unhappy French couple (Emmanuelle Devos and Mathieu Amalric) living in too-close quarters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arrête ou je continue

results.headline: The Upside of Magical Thinking
results.summary_short: In Alexandre Rockwell’s “Little Feet,” two motherless Los Angeles children deal resourcefully with the death of a pet fish.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Feet

results.headline: Noir Days of Sun, Los Angeles Smog and Marijuana Haze
results.summary_short: “Inherent Vice,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s adaptation of the Thomas Pynchon novel, is a labyrinthine noir set in sunny Los Angeles, circa 1970.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inherent Vice

results.headline: One Man’s Crisis of the Soul (It’s a Comedy)
results.summary_short: In “Top Five,” Chris Rock and a rich lineup of fellow comedians tell the story of an actor who wrestles with his identity as he tries his hand at a serious film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Top Five

results.headline: The Eyes of a Beholder of Hardship
results.summary_short: “The Salt of the Earth,” a film by Wim Wenders and Juliano Ribeiro Salgado, illustrates the way Sebastião Salgado’s photographs create beauty by capturing pain, violence and deprivation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Salt of the Earth

results.headline: Agitating for Change in the Face of Tyranny
results.summary_short: “We Are the Giant,” an Arab Spring documentary by Greg Barker, profiles seven charismatic activists agitating for change in Libya, Syria and Bahrain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are The Giant

results.headline: A Delusion and a Dream House Share Space
results.summary_short: In “Theo’s House,” Hannu-Pekka Bjorkman is an architect with regrets and a dream project.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Theo's House

results.headline: 12 at the Easel, Painting a Poet’s Life
results.summary_short: “The Color of Time,” a montage of the life of the poet C. K. Williams, features James Franco and Jessica Chastain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Color of Time

results.headline: Stockholm Syndrome, With an Overlay of Wintry Ontario
results.summary_short: In Atom Egoyan’s gray-tinged “The Captive,” a couple’s relationship frays after a man abducts their daughter, and detectives have difficulty solving the case.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Captive

results.headline: A Coming-of-Age Tale on Ice
results.summary_short: “Skating to New York” follows four Canadian high school friends and a kid brother who spend one of the coldest days of the year trying to skate across Lake Ontario.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skating to New York

results.headline: So Many Faces Make Up One Crowd
results.summary_short: The documentary “Maidan,” filmed during protests in Ukraine, focuses on the physical movement of crowds.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maidan

results.headline: Internal Affairs Police Who Don’t Confine Snooping to Work
results.summary_short: In “Tip Top,” a pair of internal affairs officers in France bring their personal eccentricities to their investigation of the death of an informant from Algeria.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tip Top

results.display_title: Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks
results.headline: Ms. Self-Pity, Meet Mr. Self-Destructive
results.summary_short: “Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks” is an odd-couple comedy about a prim older woman and her dance teacher, a young gay man.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Six Dance Lessons in Six Weeks

results.headline: Going Topless as a Cause
results.summary_short: “Free the Nipple,” directed by Lina Esco, presents itself as part of a broader movement that advocates for a woman’s right to go topless in public.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free the Nipple

results.headline: A Comedic Sprinter Tries a Marathon
results.summary_short: “Expelled” features Cameron Dallas, a star of Vine, the site of six-second videos, as a student trying to hide his expulsion from high school.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expelled

results.headline: Moses Is Back, Bearing Tablets and Strange Accents
results.summary_short: “Exodus: Gods and Kings” is Ridley Scott’s attempt to bring a famous chunk of the Hebrew Bible to life in 3-D.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exodus: Gods And Kings

results.display_title: Do You Know What My Name Is?
results.headline: Putting a Face on Memory Loss and Recovery
results.summary_short: A documentary presents a treatment for Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia, while it offers profiles of people suffering from the disease.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Do You Know What My Name Is?

results.headline: A Chess Knight and a Lonely Little Damsel
results.summary_short: In “A Little Game,” a curmudgeonly chess player in Washington Square Park helps a 10-year-old who is mocked at school for her lack of chess knowledge.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Game

results.headline: Goody-Two-Shoes Loses His Footing
results.summary_short: An insurance agent who was fired from his job turns to a life of crime to support his family in Saar Klein’s “After the Fall.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After the Fall
